G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified if there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the last judgment and if modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the same standard applies to modifications of custody or parenting orders involving unmarried parents.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court under G.L. c. 215, § 6 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, because the original custody judgment was issued by this Court and both parties and the child reside within or are subject to the jurisdiction of this Court.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Since entry of the April 15, 2021 Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances within the meaning of Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981), and Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: Schuler squarely states the governing standard for modification of alimony/child support orders: the moving party must show a material change of circumstances since the earlier judgment. Although the court ultimately finds no such change on the facts before it, the opinion is properly cited for the legal principle that a substantial and material change in circumstances is required to modify an existing order. Thus it supports using the case as authority for the need to demonstrate a material change since the April 15, 2021 order.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Since entry of the April 15, 2021 Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances within the meaning of Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981), and Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Bouchard concerns standards for making an initial child custody determination and emphasizes that the governing principle is the child’s welfare and that all relevant factors must be weighed. It does not address modification standards or what constitutes a “substantial and material change in circumstances” as in Schuler. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about post-judgment change of circumstances.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’”

Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.raw_text: Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555 (1980)
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.proposition: These conditions have already resulted in increased anxiety and stress for the minor child, demonstrating that the prior arrangement is no longer consistent with her best interests as required by Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555 (1980) and Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.support_reasoning: Haas v. Puchalski concerns the standard for modifying custody: there must be a relevant change in circumstances and the child’s welfare/best interests are paramount. It does not discuss increased anxiety or stress of the child, nor does it hold that such emotional impact shows the prior arrangement is no longer in the child’s best interests. The proposition about current conditions causing anxiety rendering the prior arrangement inconsistent with best interests is an application of the general ‘best interests’ and ‘change in circumstances’ standard, but not something specifically articulated in Haas.
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.relevant_excerpt: “The original judgment awarding custody to Michele must be presumed to have been right… It was designed to endure until facts brought to the attention of the court should require a change… To warrant a transfer of custody from one parent to another, following a determination of custody in a divorce proceeding, there must be a relevant change in circumstances… ‘This is not a proceeding to discipline [Michele] for her shortcomings… It is a proceeding solely with reference to the custody of a little [child].’”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: These conditions have already resulted in increased anxiety and stress for the minor child, demonstrating that the prior arrangement is no longer consistent with her best interests as required by Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555 (1980) and Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas concerns standards for relocation of children by a custodial parent and the general ‘best interests’ and ‘real advantage’ framework, not a finding that existing conditions have caused increased anxiety and stress in a child such that a prior arrangement is no longer in the child’s best interests. The opinion does not discuss child anxiety or stress as a change in circumstances undermining an existing custodial or visitation arrangement. Citing Yannas for that specific factual proposition misstates its holding and reasoning.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)….”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The child’s needs and daily routines must be prioritized under Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001), which holds that custody and parenting orders should reflect the child’s welfare, academic stability, and emotional well-being.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The court repeatedly frames both custody modification and removal in terms of the child’s welfare, stability, and emotional well‑being. It stresses that custody changes must be conducive to the child’s welfare, that uprooting a child requires compelling reasons, and that removal analysis must include the child’s emotional, physical, developmental needs and schooling. The opinion also remands with explicit direction to consider timing of school transitions, showing emphasis on academic stability as part of the child’s best interests.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings…that…there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle…namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’…‘The uprooting of a child…should be done only for compelling reasons.’…[The judge considered] that Caleb was found to be doing well in school… However, there are no findings, and no evidence suggesting, that Caleb would not continue to do well emotionally, physically, and developmentally if the removal were allowed.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation of a parent or change in proximity constitutes a *material change* warranting review of custodial arrangements: Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); Malachi M. v. Quintina Q., 483 Mass. 725 (2019); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); and Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2019).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman concerns a removal petition under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and applies a best‑interests standard to decide whether a jointly custodial parent may relocate out of state with the children. The opinion does not frame relocation or change in proximity as a “material change in circumstances” triggering a modification of custody; instead it assumes jurisdiction under the removal statute and then conducts a best‑interests analysis. The only “substantial change in circumstances” language appears in a block quote from the ALI Principles, as secondary authority, not as a holding of the Massachusetts court. Thus Mason does not stand for the proposition that relocation itself is a material change requiring review of custodial arrangements.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:

‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce],’ …

ALI Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution, supra … supports the view that where ‘neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility,’ the effect of the relocation on the child is a ‘relevant factor[]’ in determining the child’s best interests.”

Malachi M. v. Quintina Q., 483 Mass. 725.raw_text: Malachi M. v. Quintina Q., 483 Mass. 725 (2019)
Malachi M. v. Quintina Q., 483 Mass. 725.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation of a parent or change in proximity constitutes a *material change* warranting review of custodial arrangements: Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); Malachi M. v. Quintina Q., 483 Mass. 725 (2019); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); and Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2019).

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation of a parent or change in proximity constitutes a *material change* warranting review of custodial arrangements: Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); Malachi M. v. Quintina Q., 483 Mass. 725 (2019); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); and Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2019).
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation decision, but it is not framed as a modification based on a prior custody order being reconsidered due to a material change; rather, it applies the Yannas ‘real advantage/best interests’ framework under G.L. c. 208, § 30. The court does not characterize the proposed relocation or change in proximity as a ‘material change in circumstances’ warranting review of custodial arrangements, nor does it discuss that standard in the removal context. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific ‘material change’ proposition for which it is cited.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “The mother, Dawn Michelle Murray, appeals from a judgment of the Probate and Family Court dismissing her complaint for modification, which sought to remove the minor children of the marriage to the State of California. Where the parent seeking to move has primary physical custody of the children, the standard governing removal of the minor children from the Commonwealth requires a determination whether there is a real advantage to the custodial parent and consideration of the best interests of the children and the interests of both parents. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710-711 (1985).”

Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2.raw_text: Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2019)
Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that relocation of a parent or change in proximity constitutes a *material change* warranting review of custodial arrangements: Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); Malachi M. v. Quintina Q., 483 Mass. 725 (2019); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); and Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2019).

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The controlling principle remains the child’s best interests, considering academic stability, continuity, and minimizing disruption—see Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); and Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reaffirms that the controlling standard in custody determinations is the child’s best interests and applies that standard by emphasizing factors like minimizing disruption to the children and fostering a stable, healthy environment. In discussing why sole custody with the mother is appropriate and joint custody inappropriate, the court highlights continuity of the primary caregiver, the children’s strongest bond, and the need for an arrangement that minimizes disruption to their growth and development, which aligns with the cited proposition about best interests, stability, and minimizing disruption.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The controlling principle remains the child’s best interests, considering academic stability, continuity, and minimizing disruption—see Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); and Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies the best-interests-of-the-child standard in resolving a custody dispute and identifies relevant factors including stability of each parent’s home, work-schedule flexibility, maintenance of sibling relationships, and each parent’s willingness not to disrupt the child’s relationship with the other parent. While it does not use the exact phrase “academic stability” or “minimizing disruption,” it explicitly emphasizes stability of living circumstances, continuity of relationships, and avoidance of harmful disruption to the child’s attachments, which aligns with the proposition. The court also cites Williams v. Massa in this best-interests analysis, supporting the continuity/minimizing-disruption principle.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. … See generally Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 623-624 (2000) … .” (463 Mass. at 494-495).

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: The controlling principle remains the child’s best interests, considering academic stability, continuity, and minimizing disruption—see Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); and Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: Williams v. Massa involves custody, but the discussion is narrow: it corrects the procedure for modifying legal custody (requiring a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28) and briefly notes the judge’s assessment of the parents’ respective parenting capacities. It does not articulate or analyze a general best‑interests standard focused on academic stability, continuity, or minimizing disruption, nor does it cite Rolde or develop those factors. Using Williams as authority for that specific ‘controlling principle’ overstates what the case holds.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father.”
